person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_263.name: Pluto
person_263.description: The ruler of the underworld in ancient Greek mythology and religion.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

person_307.name: René JustHaüy
person_307.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_489.name: Cnut
person_489.description: King of England, Denmark and Norway between 1016 and 1035. At Bosham, alledgedly ordered the tide to reverse.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_298.name: HenryPemberton
person_298.description: An English physician and man of letters, who edited the third edition of Isaac Newton's Principia Mathematica. FRSL.

person_299.name: IsaacBarrow
person_299.description: First Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge University. Isaac Newton was his student. FRSL.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_231.name: JosephBlack
person_231.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_274.name: LadyC.
person_274.description: Untraced, probably the wife of Charles-Louis Cadet.

person_275.name: Prometheus
person_275.description: In Greek mythology, defied the Olympian gods by stealing fire and giving it to humans.

person_276.name: UlisseAldrovandi
person_276.description: Italian naturalist and father of natural history according to Buffon and Linneaus.

person_247.name: CarlLinnaeus
person_247.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

person_088.name: SamuelJohnson
person_088.description: Johnson was a poet, novelist, essayist, playwright and lexicographer.

person_277.name: Theophrastus
person_277.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_221.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
person_221.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

person_278.name: SchweitzerJohann Friedrich
person_278.description: Dutch physician and alchemical writer, usually known as Helvetius.

person_279.name: SlareFrederick
person_279.description: Physician and chemist who worked for Robert Boyle. FRSL.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_284.name: Mrs S.Turner
person_284.description: Dates untraced. Female subscriber at Royal Institution, full details untraced.

person_285.name: MissSlater
person_285.description: Dates untraced. Female subscriber at Royal Institution, full details untraced.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_165.name: WilliamHiggins
person_165.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_286.name: CharlesRoyce
person_286.description: Assisted Royal Institution lecturers, including Davy, bewteen 1802 and 1808.

person_287.name: ThomasWebster
person_287.description: Assisted lecturers at the RI, including making transparencies use in Davy's courses of lectures on geology.

person_288.name: ThomasBernard
person_288.description: Philantropist and a founding member of the Royal Institution serving as an early Treasurer. Later influential in running the institution, especially its lecture programme.

person_289.name: GeorgeShaw
person_289.description: Assistant Keeper and then Keeper of natural history at the British Museum. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

person_039.name: JohnWoodward
person_039.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_261.name: GregoryWatt
person_261.description: Youngest son of James Watt. Lodged with Davy's mother in Penzance during the winter of 1797-8 and became close friends with Davy.

person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_301.name: RobertJameson
person_301.description: Scottish geologist and Regius Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh. FRSL.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_302.name: Johann JakobScheuchzer
person_302.description: Swiss geologist and palaeontologist within a Biblical context. He was a diluvialist and believed that rock strata and fossils were deposited during the Great Flood. His account of the supposed remains of a human who witnessed the flood (Homo Diluvii Testis) was published in Latin in 1726. ForMemRSL.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

person_306.name: AthanasiusKircher
person_306.description: Prolific German Jesuit scholar and polymath who published many book, including on geology.

person_304.name: DenisPapin
person_304.description: French-born assistant in the Royal Society of London. Developed an early form of the steam engine. FRSL.

person_146.name: JamesWatt
person_146.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

place_365.name: London Institution
place_365.description: The London Institution was founded in 1806. Francis Baring (1740–1810), a wealthy banker, was an instigator of the London Institution and became its first President.

place_368.name: Axbridge
place_368.description: Possibly the small town of Axbridge in Somerset.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_370.name: Rowley Hills
place_370.description: A range of hills in the West Midlands, England.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_323.name: Cambridge
place_323.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_399.name: Dublin
place_399.description: The capital city of the Republic of Ireland.

place_1363.name: River Tees
place_1363.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

place_224.name: Royal Institution
place_224.description: The RI Building is at 21 Albermarle Street, London.

place_397.name: Dartmoor
place_397.description: Dartmoor is an upland area of southern Devon, England.

place_286.name: Leicestershire
place_286.description: A county in the East Midlands of England.
